articles.description:
SHOPIAN, INDIA, Nov 02 (IPS) - Of Kashmir’s seven million inhabitants, a staggering one million rely directly on apple farming. The region is pivotal in India’s apple and horticulture production, contributing to over 70 percent of the country’s apple supply. This not only provides income to farmers but also sustains a vast network of laborers, traders, and transporters within the fruit economy.

Read the full story, “Kashmir's Apple Industry Faces Dire Threats as Climate Change Takes its Toll”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Kashmir's Apple Industry Faces Dire Threats as Climate Change Takes its Toll

articles.description:
ACAPULCO, Mexico, Nov 02 (IPS) - Acapulco is a paradise. A port of golden sunsets, toasted sand, and deep blue sea. Its dream beaches captivated the hearts of Elvis Presley and Elizabeth Taylor. US President John F. Kennedy chose its shores to spend his honeymoon with Jackie Kennedy. Its luxury hotels and the untamed sea made it the most famous tourist destination in Mexico.

Read the full story, “Hurricane Otis and the Indifference Toward the Children of Acapulco”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Hurricane Otis and the Indifference Toward the Children of Acapulco

articles.title: Iran urged to end new rights clampdown following teenage girl’s death

articles.description:
New data from the UN Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) has revealed a worrying rise in violence against journalists during election periods, and usually at the hands of law enforcement agents.

Read the full story, “Day highlighting journalists under fire focuses on protection during elections”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Day highlighting journalists under fire focuses on protection during elections

articles.description:
The UN General Assembly is expected to vote on its annual resolution later on Thursday in New York which calls on the United States to end its economic and trade embargo against Cuba, first imposed in 1960. Follow our live coverage as the vote on the resolution nears...

Read the full story, “UPDATING LIVE: UN General Assembly debates US embargo against Cuba”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: UPDATING LIVE: UN General Assembly debates US embargo against Cuba

articles.description:
The number of people killed in Gaza is nearing the 9,000 mark amid mounting concerns over the aftermath of Israeli airstrikes on a densely-populated refugee camp near Gaza City, while a key hospital has stopped operations and UN humanitarians are unable to deliver aid to the north as the ground war intensifies.

Read the full story, “Israel-Palestine crisis: Gaza’s north cut off from aid; death toll rising”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Israel-Palestine crisis: Gaza’s north cut off from aid; death toll rising

articles.description:
Instead of accelerating to meet the challenge of rising emissions, progress on climate adaptation is slowing across the board, a new report published on Thursday by the UN’s environment agency finds.

Read the full story, “Climate action: ‘Take steps to close the adaptation gap, now’”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Climate action: ‘Take steps to close the adaptation gap, now’

articles.description:
CHIPATA, ZAMBIA, Nov 01 (IPS) - As we approach the forest in the village to appreciate Andrew Mbewe’s beekeeping enterprise, a bee from a hive close to the edge of the natural woodland stings him on the cheek.

Read the full story, “Communities Taking a Sting Out of Poaching With Alternative Livelihoods”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Communities Taking a Sting Out of Poaching With Alternative Livelihoods

articles.description:
UNITED NATIONS, Nov 01 (IPS) - In an address to the UN Security CouncilThank you for your presence here with us in New York, and for the special dedication that Brazil has given to peace in our region.

I also pay special tribute to our briefers, and to their teams’ dedicated work in the most unimaginable circumstances on the ground in the Gaza Strip.

Read the full story, “The Killings in Gaza Should Stain Our Moral Conscience”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: The Killings in Gaza Should Stain Our Moral Conscience

articles.description:
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Nov 01 (IPS) - Governments the world over are worried about investor-state dispute settlement (ISDS) rules. These allow foreign investors to sue them for billions over new laws or policies reducing their profits.

Read the full story, “Even Rich Nations Now Worried About Investor-State Dispute Settlements”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Even Rich Nations Now Worried About Investor-State Dispute Settlements

articles.description:
Several blue helmets were “seriously injured” during the departure of the last contingent of peacekeepers from the restive Kidal region of Mali, the UN Spokesperson said on Wednesday.

Read the full story, “World News in Brief: Mali mission latest, starvation alert for ‘hotspots’, inclusive sport for all”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: World News in Brief: Mali mission latest, starvation alert for ‘hotspots’, inclusive sport for all

articles.description:
More than 820 Palestinians in the occupied West Bank have been displaced amid settler violence and increased movement restrictions since the Hamas terror attacks of 7 October and the start of Israel’s assault on Gaza, the UN relief wing said on Wednesday.

Read the full story, “Rise in intimidation, settler violence in the West Bank, warns OCHA”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Rise in intimidation, settler violence in the West Bank, warns OCHA

articles.description:
UN health agency chief Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus welcomed Egypt’s decision on Wednesday to accept dozens of the most critically sick and injured from the stricken Gaza Strip for treatment. Meanwhile, the UN relief chief has said a "step change" is needed in what has now become "a global crisis."

Read the full story, “UPDATED: Israel-Palestine crisis: UN welcomes first medical evacuations from Gaza”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: UPDATED: Israel-Palestine crisis: UN welcomes first medical evacuations from Gaza

articles.description:
MILAN, Italy, Oct 31 (IPS) - It all fits into an off-road vehicle that can reach even the most remote parts of Southern Africa to bring cinema where the essentials are lacking, where there's no electricity to power a projector, and where perhaps no one has ever sat in front of a screen to watch a movie. With just the sun and a solar panel, a theater can be set up in areas where people struggle to access food and water and make a decent living. But what it truly requires is the courage to not view creativity as a luxury. Sydelle and Rowand, the founders of Sunshine Cinema, a network of mobile movie theaters, are not just entertaining people; they are crossing a bridge.

Read the full story, “Can Creativity Change the World?”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Can Creativity Change the World?

articles.description:
NAIROBI, Oct 31 (IPS) - Excluded by inheritance and ignored by big business, women farmers in Kenya are turning to innovative methods to become independent food producers and get the financial backing to ensure their success. Creating resilience is crucial to adapting to climate change and ensuring climate justice.  Although women account for more than three-quarters of the agricultural labour force and manage 40 percent of small-scale farms, historically, they neither owned nor controlled the land because land rights were passed down to male relatives. It is a historic gender injustice whereby women could only access land through close male relatives.

Read the full story, “Women Correct Historical Injustices, Build Climate Resilience Through Cash Pooling”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Women Correct Historical Injustices, Build Climate Resilience Through Cash Pooling

articles.description:
KARACHI, Oct 31 (IPS) - After months of warding off appeals from his employers to get vaccinated for the COVID-19 disease, Mohammad Yusuf, 24, working as a live-in domestic worker in Karachi’s Clifton area, finally relented and got his first shot.

Read the full story, “COVID-19 Vaccine Hesitancy: Sharing 'Real-Time' Data, Consistent, Simple Messaging Helps”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: COVID-19 Vaccine Hesitancy: Sharing 'Real-Time' Data, Consistent, Simple Messaging Helps

articles.description:
SAN FRANCISCO, USA, Oct 31 (IPS) - For three weeks, President Biden has played a key role in backing Israel’s war crimes while touting himself as a compassionate advocate of restraint. That pretense is lethal nonsense as Israel persists with mass killing of civilians in Gaza.

Read the full story, “Biden Is a Genocide Denier and Enabler in Chief for Israel's Ongoing War Crimes”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Biden Is a Genocide Denier and Enabler in Chief for Israel's Ongoing War Crimes

articles.description:
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct 31 (IPS) - In 1968, the tobacco company Philip Morris introduced a new cigarette brand called Virginia Slims. Under the slogan “You’ve come a long way, baby” it was exclusively marketed to women. The advertising campaign exploited the civil rights movements of the 1960s, indicating that those cigarettes were enjoyed by strong, independent, and liberated women.

A blatant lie – why would “independent” women choose to poison themselves with a commodity which each year causes more than 480,000 deaths in the US alone – nearly one in five deaths? Another question arising from this deceitful ad is: “How far have women come on their way to independence and liberation?”

Read the full story, “Women and War”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Women and War

articles.author: Suzanne Kelly
articles.description:
EXPERT PERSPECTIVE / OPINION — When Russian President Vladimir Putin rose to power in the late 1990’s and early 2000’s, one of his promises to [...] More 
The post The Price of Putin’s Unkept Promises appeared first on The Cipher Brief.
articles.title: The Price of Putin’s Unkept Promises
Want Cash Out of Your Home? Here Are Your Best Options
Turn Your Rising Home Equity Into Cash You Can Use
Dream Big with a Home Equity Loan

sources.title: World News Headlines, Latest International News, World Breaking News - Times of India

articles.description: A man's body was discovered inside a discarded suitcase during a routine cleanup around Oakland's Lake Merritt on Halloween. Volunteers found the body when they realized the suitcase was too heavy and unzipped it. The victim, believed to be in his 30s, was found in a fetal position. The investigation is ongoing, and authorities are trying to determine where the body could have come from. The incident has caused shock among local residents who consider the area a peaceful spot.
articles.title: Volunteers cleaning California lake on Halloween find 'murdered' man in suitcase

articles.description: A clothing company has been ordered to pay over $1 million to four American Airlines flight attendants who claimed that their uniforms caused health problems. The attendants attributed their rashes, headaches, and breathing issues to chemicals used in the production of the uniforms. The verdict may lead to further legal challenges, as more than 400 other flight attendants have made similar claims against the uniform manufacturer. American Airlines has since terminated its contract with the company and switched to a new uniform supplier.
articles.title: Flight attendants who blamed clothing company for health issues win California lawsuit

articles.description: A man in Florida has been arrested and charged with felony child abuse for allegedly attempting to circumcise a toddler he was babysitting. Timothoes Powell, 29, was taken into custody on Monday and is facing a first-degree aggravated child abuse charge. The incident came to light when a state Department of Children and Families investigator noticed the child's injuries. Powell initially claimed that he found a piece of glass in the child's diaper, but later admitted to causing the injury.
articles.title: Florida babysitter arrested for attempting to 'circumcise' toddler

articles.description: Secretary of State Antony Blinken will request brief cessations of military operations in Gaza from the Israeli government to allow for hostage releases and humanitarian aid distribution. This comes as President Biden revealed that Prime Minister Netanyahu had agreed to a temporary halt in shelling on October 20th for the release of two American hostages. The US is pushing for "humanitarian pauses" to address the urgent crisis for civilians in Gaza.
articles.title: United States to press Israel for 'pauses' in war against Hamas

articles.description: British prime minister Rishi Sunak on Thursday said that like-minded governments and artificial intelligence companies had reached agreement on testing new AI models before they were released. Sunak is hosting a 2-day AI Safety Summit where on Wednesday he secured China's backing for an international effort to manage the risks of the technology. On Thursday, Sunak announced a further "landmark agreement" with "like-minded governments and AI companies."
articles.title: Sunak unveils 'landmark' deal on safety testing of new AI models

articles.description: Israeli troops continued to fight with Hamas militants in Gaza City as the Palestinian death toll surpassed 9,000. US and Arab leaders urged Israel to ease its siege and temporarily halt attacks to aid civilians. US Secretary of State Antony Blinken planned to visit Israel and Jordan for talks. President Joe Biden suggested a humanitarian pause, but Israel did not immediately respond. Arab countries, including Jordan and Egypt, expressed unease with the war.
articles.title: Pressure on Israel to pause war as Gaza toll crosses 9 thousand

articles.description: Mohammadi has subsequently announced she would not under any circumstances wear a hijab, the head covering which has been obligatory for women in public spaces since shortly after Iran's 1979 Islamic revolution. Prison authorities in response have refused to transfer Mohammadi, who suffers from heart and lung conditions, to a hospital outside Evin, her family said in a statement, warning her health and life were at risk. The scan showed two veins with severe blockages and high lung pressure, with a coronary angiogram and lung scan urgently needed.
articles.title: Iran limiting jailed Nobel winner Narges Mohammadi's medical care over hijab refusal: Family

articles.description: The number of Americans applying for jobless benefits increased slightly last week but remains relatively low, despite the Federal Reserve's efforts to cool the economy and control inflation. Unemployment claims rose by 5,000 to 217,000 for the week ending October 28. The four-week moving average of claims also ticked up by 2,000 to 210,000. However, the American labor market continues to show resilience, with the economy adding jobs and consumer spending remaining strong.
articles.title: US applications for jobless benefits inch higher but remain at historically healthy levels

articles.description: Ukraine has stated that Russian attacks on the town of Avdiivka have decreased, but the Kremlin denies that the conflict is deadlocked. Avdiivka has been a focal point of fighting between Ukrainian and Russian forces since 2014. Ukrainian President Zelensky confirmed that his forces are mounting defensive actions in Avdiivka. While there are concerns that Russian forces may be regrouping for another wave of attacks, Ukraine claims to be largely in control. Both sides have struggled to make significant progress on the battlefield in recent months.
articles.title: Ukraine says Russian attacks easing around embattled town

articles.description: Two Lebanese shepherds were found dead near the border after being shot by Israeli forces. The Israeli army is looking into the report. The shepherds were tending to their flock near the Wazzani river. The incident occurred amid ongoing exchange of fire between Israeli forces and Hezbollah along the border. UNIFIL, the UN peacekeeping force, had been asked to assist in evacuating two injured individuals in the same area. The search for the injured was postponed until the next morning due to darkness and land mines.
articles.title: Bodies of Lebanese shepherds shot at by Israeli forces found-report

articles.description: US Vice President Kamala Harris and British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak are participating in a UK summit focused on addressing the risks associated with advanced artificial intelligence (AI). The summit, held at Bletchley Park, began with an agreement signed by 28 nations, including the US and China, to collaborate on understanding and managing AI risks. The summit aims to foster dialogue and cooperation rather than impose binding regulations.Sunak is expected to provide further details on his proposal for a global expert panel on AI.
articles.title: Harris and Sunak due to discuss cutting-edge AI risks at UK summit

articles.description: President Vladimir Putin has signed a bill to revoke Russia's ratification of the Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty (CTBT), citing the need to establish parity with the United States. The CTBT, adopted in 1996, bans nuclear explosions globally but has not been fully implemented. Russia's move has raised concerns that it may resume nuclear tests to deter Western military support for Ukraine. However, Russian Deputy Foreign Minister Sergei Ryabkov stated that Moscow will only resume tests if the US does so first.
articles.title: Putin signs bill revoking Russia's ratification of global nuke test ban treaty

articles.description: Thousands of people are flooding Pakistan's northwestern border crossing into Afghanistan after the government's deadline for undocumented foreigners to leave expired. Pakistani authorities have been rounding up undocumented foreigners, primarily Afghans, citing their involvement in militant attacks and crime. Over a million Afghans may have to leave Pakistan or face arrest and forcible expulsion. More than 24,000 Afghans crossed into Afghanistan on Wednesday alone, with thousands more expected to follow.
articles.title: Pakistan-Afghanistan border crossing overwhelmed as Afghans face expulsion

articles.description: Egypt has announced that it will help evacuate around 7,000 foreigners and dual nationals from the war-torn Gaza Strip. The Rafah border crossing opened on Wednesday for the first time in weeks, allowing people to leave Gaza. Around 400 people were expected to cross on Thursday, including 60 wounded individuals. The exact timeline and details of the evacuation were not provided. The Egyptian official clarified that 361 foreigners and dual nationals had entered Egypt on Wednesday. The number of wounded included 46 patients and 30 accompanying individuals.
articles.title: Egypt says to help evacuate 'about 7,000' Gaza foreign nationals

articles.description: An earthquake of magnitude 5.7 struck the central Philippines on Tuesday, the USGS said. The offshore quake was at a depth of 19.2 km (12 miles), USGS said, off the central province of Eastern Samar. The Philippine Institute of Volcanology and Seismology warned of damage and aftershocks in an advisory but there were no immediate reports of casualties. The Philippines lies on the "Ring of Fire", a belt of volcanoes circling the Pacific Ocean that is prone to earthquakes.
articles.title: Magnitude 5.7 earthquake strikes central Philippines: USGS

articles.author: Asmita Dey
articles.description: India Business News: NEW DELHI: As it looks to widen its focus on the Gen Z segment, stock broking platform Angel One has acquired the team of Bengaluru-based fintech star.
articles.title: Angel One acquires fintech startup Dstreet

articles.description: An investigation is underway in China regarding a fraudulent "tumor research institute" where a woman's mother was deceived into paying $27,000 for fake cancer treatments. The woman and her mother were introduced to a traditional Chinese medicine practitioner who claimed to have a cure for cancer. The practitioner administered questionable treatments, including bloodletting and applying cement to the skin. It was later revealed that the practitioner had no medical qualifications and the certificates he provided were fake.
articles.title: China’s ‘tumor research institute’ scam: Woman duped during bizarre cancer treatment

articles.description: South Korea's military has assessed that North Korea has likely supplied various types of missiles to Russia to support its war in Ukraine. This comes after reports that North Korea provided over a million artillery shells to Russia. The military believes that North Korea has also sent short-range ballistic missiles, anti-tank missiles, and portable anti-air missiles to Russia, among other weapons. South Korea, the US, and Japan have condemned these weapons shipments, which violate UN Security Council resolutions.
articles.title: North Korea has likely sent missiles, ammunition, shells to Russia, Seoul says

articles.description: Rest of World News: MANILA: The Philippine foreign ministry on Thursday accused China of intruding into its waters after an incident at a disputed shoal in the South Chin.
articles.title: Philippines accuses China of intruding into its waters

articles.description: Four crew members died Wednesday when an air ambulance crashed in the central Mexican state of Morelos. The incident took place just before 14:30 p.m. local time, in a wooded, mountainous area near the town of Tetlama, Temixco: a township roughly 30 miles (50 kilometers) south of Mexico City. Officials from the army, National Guard and state security departments responded to the crash, the state department for civil protection reported on X, the social network formerly known as Twitter.
articles.title: Air ambulance crash kills 4 crew members in central Mexico

articles.description: Islamic extremist rebels in northeastern Nigeria killed at least 37 villagers in two separate attacks, marking a resurgence of violence in the region. The first attack occurred in Yobe state's Geidam district, where gunmen shot and killed 17 villagers. The following day, a land mine exploded, killing 20 people attending the burial of the victims from the previous attack. The Boko Haram group has been responsible for the insurgency in Nigeria since 2009, resulting in over 35,000 deaths and the displacement of millions of people.
articles.title: Extremists kill 37 villagers in latest attack in Nigeria's hard-hit northeast

articles.description: China and the United States are set to hold their first nuclear arms control talks since the Obama administration. The discussions, scheduled for next week, will focus on arms control and non-proliferation, as well as maritime affairs and other issues. The talks come after US officials expressed frustration over China's lack of interest in reducing nuclear weapons risks. China currently has over 500 operational nuclear warheads, a number that is expected to rise to over 1,000 by 2030.
articles.title: China agrees to nuclear arms-control talks with US: Report

articles.description: Six terrorists were killed during an operation in the Sambaza area of Balochistan's Zhob district. Security forces conducted the operation based on intelligence reports. The Inter-Services Public Relations (ISPR) stated that the terrorists were involved in activities against security forces and targeting innocent civilians. A cache of arms, ammunition, and explosives was also recovered. The area is being sanitized to eliminate other militants. Pakistan has witnessed an increase in terrorism, particularly in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa and Balochistan.
articles.title: Pakistan: Six terrorists killed in Balochistan's Zhob

articles.description: President Joe Biden will visit the community of Lewiston, Maine, to mourn the victims of the deadliest mass shooting in the state's history. The shooting took place on October 25, resulting in 18 deaths and 13 injuries. Biden and First Lady Jill Biden will pay their respects to the victims, meet with first responders, and grieve with the community. The alleged gunman, Robert Card, was found dead of an apparent suicide after a manhunt. Investigators are focusing on Card's mental health as a possible motive.
articles.title: Biden and the first lady will travel to Maine to mourn with the community after the mass shooting

articles.description: Donald Trump Jr testified in a civil fraud trial that he never worked on his father's financial statements, which are at the center of the trial. The lawsuit alleges that the former president and his business misled banks and insurers by inflating his net worth on the statements. Trump Jr said he signed off on the statements as a trustee but left the work to outside accountants. Eric Trump is also expected to testify in the trial, followed by the former president himself. The trial is in its second month and is being closely watched.
articles.title: Donald Trump Jr testifies he never worked on the key documents in his father's civil fraud trial

articles.description: A US couple has been fined $28,000 by a court in Uganda after pleading guilty to child cruelty and "inhumane treatment" of their 10-year-old foster child. The couple admitted to making the child sleep on a wooden platform and feeding him cold food. They were sentenced to two months in prison, which they have already served, and ordered to pay the victim $26,000 in compensation. The case has sparked criticism from child rights activists in Uganda, who have called it a travesty of justice.
articles.title: Uganda court fines US couple $28,000 for 'inhumane treatment' of their foster child

articles.description: Hostels in China have become refuges for young people struggling to find jobs in major cities. As joblessness among young Chinese reaches record highs, hostels provide a place for individuals to stay between interviews and strategize for their next networking meeting. The hypercompetitive nature of China's white-collar job market, combined with a slowing economy, has made it increasingly difficult for young people to secure well-paying jobs. Even those who have found employment often struggle to afford housing. The situation has worsened in recent years, with fewer job offers available.
articles.title: For China's jobless young people, hostels are the place to be

articles.description: A Sikh man was killed by an American, after a minor car crash in October, was motivated by "rage inflamed by hate," the Queens district attorney said. The accused Gilbert Augustin following the crash repeatedly beat the victim, Jasmer Singh and called him "turban man." The new charges filed against him Tuesday included manslaughter and assault as hate crimes. Augustin faces up to 25 years in prison if convicted.
articles.title: US man who beat Sikh man to death faces hate charge

articles.description: At least 43 military aircraft and seven ships China sent to Taiwan, a  latest sign that Beijing plans no let-up in its campaign of harassment, threats and intimidation. Taiwan's defence ministry said 37 of the aircraft had crossed the median line in the Taiwan Strait, which China no longer recognises as an informal divider between the sides.
articles.title: China sends 43 aircraft, 7 ships close to Taiwan

articles.author: Ch Sushil Rao
articles.description: A 29-year-old student from Telangana, India, named Putcha Varun Raj, was stabbed in the head by a man at a gym in Indiana, United States. The attacker, Jordan Andrade, claimed that he found Varun "a little weird" and felt threatened by him. Varun, who was pursuing his MS in computer science, had a slim chance of survival due to the severity of his injuries. Varun's family has requested assistance from the government, and the Indian embassy and NRIs from Telangana have pledged their support.
articles.title: 29-year-old Indian student stabbed at gym in US, critical

articles.description: Actor Matthew Perry was found unresponsive and not breathing in his hot tub at his California residence. The Los Angeles Fire Department arrived at the scene but Perry was already deceased. An autopsy has been completed, but the cause of death has been deferred pending further tests. Foul play is not suspected at this time. Perry was best known for his role as Chandler Bing on the sitcom "Friends," and his co-stars have expressed their grief over his loss.
articles.title: New details emerge after Matthew Perry's autopsy, cause of death 'deferred'

articles.description: American commandos are assisting Israel in locating and rescuing the hostages taken during Hamas' cross-border attacks. The US Special Operations forces are working alongside FBI and state department experts to coordinate efforts with Israeli counterparts. While the commandos are not assigned combat roles, they are advising on the complexities of a potential ground invasion of Gaza. The US forces in the region are also prepared to assist American citizens and secure embassies if needed. The exact number of commandos deployed has not been disclosed.
articles.title: US commandos on the ground in Israel helping to locate hostages

articles.description: Jordan, a key US ally, said Wednesday it has recalled its ambassador from Israel and told Israel's ambassador to remain out of the country in protest over the "humanitarian catastrophe" in Gaza. Jordan's deputy PM said the return of the ambassadors is linked to Israel "stopping its war on Gaza ... and the humanitarian catastrophe it is causing." Jordan signed a peace deal with Israel in 1994. Meanwhile, Bolivia said on Tuesday it had broken diplomatic ties with Israel
articles.title: Jordan, a key ally of US, recalls its envoy from Israel

articles.description: Countries such as India, UK, US, and China have agreed to collaborate in order to protect against the potential harm caused by artificial intelligence (AI). This agreement was reached at the world's first summit on AI safety, held in Bletchley Park, UK. The participating nations signed the "Bletchley Declaration," emphasizing the need to collectively manage the risks associated with AI. While the declaration lacks specific policy goals, a second meeting is scheduled in South Korea and a third in France.
articles.title: 28 countries and EU sign pact against AI's 'catastrophic' risks

articles.description: An Indian-origin Israeli soldier was killed while fighting against Hamas in Gaza. Staff-Sgt. Halel Solomon, 20, was from the southern Israeli town of Dimona. Dimona’s mayor, Benny Bitton took his Facebook and said, ​​“It is with great sorrow and grief that we announce the death of a son of Dimona, Halel Solomon, in the battle in Gaza."
articles.title: PIO soldier among 16 Israelis killed in a battle inside Gaza

articles.description: The Israeli military said it had deployed missile boats in the Red Sea on Wednesday as reinforcements, a day after the Iran-aligned Houthi movement said it had launched missile and drone attacks on Israel and vowed to carry out more. Images disseminated by the military showed Saar-class corvettes patrolling near Eilat port in the Red Sea, which Israel sees as a new front as its war in Gaza draws retaliation from Iran-aligned pro-Hamas forces elsewhere in the region
articles.title: Israel puts missile boats in Red Sea as Houthis attack from Yemen

articles.description: At least 320 foreign passport holders and injured Gazans were evacuated from the Palestinian enclave through the Rafah crossing into Egypt on Wednesday, under a deal mediated by Qatar. Initially, 500 foreign passport holders were expected to be allowed out of Gaza in the coming days. Talks are ongoing for further evacuations, with the US aiming to evacuate 400 Americans. The limited evacuations come after more than three weeks of a total blockade of Gaza by Israel, following an attack by Hamas fighters. Hospitals in Gaza are also facing a critical shortage of fuel.
articles.title: First evacuees exit Gaza as refugee camp struck again

articles.description: Patrick Dai, who has been accused of making violent threats against Jewish students, was arrested. He called for the deaths of Jewish people and said he was ‘gonna shoot up 104 west.'
articles.title: Cornell student held for threats to Jews

articles.description: The US Federal Reserve has decided to maintain interest rates at a 22-year high for the second consecutive meeting in an effort to control inflation without harming the strong economy. The Fed aims to cool down demand and encourage companies to slow down price increases. Despite the economy's resilience, inflation has gradually decreased from its peak in 2022. The Fed is focused on bringing inflation back in line with its 2% target and is considering whether to implement one final rate increase in the coming months.
articles.title: US Federal Reserve keeps interest rates at 22-year high

articles.description: Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni expressed international fatigue with the conflict in Ukraine and a lack of support for Italy in dealing with migration in a phone call with Russian pranksters. The 13-minute audio of the call, released by the pranksters, revealed Meloni's frustration with the situation. She also criticized the belief that Italy should solve the migration problem alone. The pranksters praised Meloni for sharing her genuine opinions, unlike other European politicians who act like programmed robots.
articles.title: Italy PM Giorgia Meloni talks of Ukraine fatigue, migration in prank call

articles.description: An Israeli strike in Gaza caused extensive damage and casualties in a densely populated neighborhood. The Gaza health ministry claimed that hundreds of people were killed and injured, although this could not be immediately verified. Israel stated that the strike targeted Hamas militants, including a commander responsible for a previous massacre. Israeli ground troops and tanks are advancing further into Gaza, while humanitarian officials warn of a growing catastrophe for Palestinian civilians.
articles.title: Israel Hits Hamas Hub In Dense Gaza

articles.description: Violence erupted in Bangladesh as opposition activists clashed with police during protests against the government. The protests, initiated by the Bangladesh Nationalist Party (BNP) and Jamaat-e-Islami, called for the resignation of Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina ahead of the upcoming elections. Two BNP members were killed, and over 100 were injured during the clashes. International concerns have been raised, with several countries calling for restraint and a fair election process. The US Ambassador has urged all sides to hold talks, but Prime Minister Hasina has rejected the call.
articles.title: Two Bangladeshi opposition activists killed in anti-government protests

articles.description: Residents of Minneapolis-Saint Paul were surprised by a significant snowfall on Halloween, with over 2.5 inches of snow covering the Twin Cities. This is one of the most substantial snowfalls in decades for the area. The last time a Halloween snowstorm of this magnitude occurred was in 1991. The snowfall ranks among the highest October accumulations for Minnesota. The morning commute was challenging due to icy road conditions, leading to numerous crashes.
articles.title: Two US cities witness biggest Halloween snowfall in over three decades

articles.description: French Prime Minister Elisabeth Borne has pledged to "mercilessly fight" against rising anti-Semitism after anti-Jewish graffiti was discovered on buildings in several districts of Paris. Borne emphasized that the situation in the Middle East does not justify anti-Semitism and that her government is determined to combat it. Since the recent Israel-Hamas conflict, French authorities have registered 857 anti-Semitic acts, prompting Interior Minister Gerald Darmanin to open investigations and assure Jewish communities of their protection.
articles.title: France vows 'merciless fight' against antisemitism after anti-Jewish graffiti found in Paris

articles.description: The Israel Defence Forces (IDF) claimed to have killed Hamas commander Ibrahim Biari in a strike in the Gaza Strip. Hamas denied his presence in the camp, but IDF said Biari was responsible for sending terrorists to carry out an attack on Israel. The strike targeted Hamas command and control, damaging their ability to direct military activity. Around 50 people were reportedly killed in the strike. IDF spokesperson Rear Admiral Daniel Hagari said the fighting in Gaza is becoming more complex as soldiers operate deeper into the region.
articles.title: Israel army confirms refugee camp bombing to kill Hamas commander

articles.description: The EU's top diplomat, Josep Borrell, has called for a pause in the Israel-Hamas conflict and condemned attacks by Israeli settlers on Palestinians in the occupied West Bank. Borrell expressed concern over the attacks and extended his concerns to related events in the West Bank. Israel has launched raids and air strikes on Gaza, resulting in numerous casualties, and has also increased operations in the West Bank. The Israeli army recently demolished the home of exiled Hamas leader Saleh al-Aruri.
articles.title: EU's top diplomat Borrell condemns West Bank attacks by Israeli settlers

articles.description: US Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin warned that Russia would be successful in Ukraine without continued US support for Kyiv. Austin made the statement during a testimony to the Senate Appropriations Committee on President Biden's request for $106 billion to fund plans for Ukraine, Israel, and US border security. Biden requested $61.4 billion for Ukraine, with half of the funds to be spent in the US to replenish weapons stocks. Congress has approved $113 billion for Ukraine since Russia's invasion in February 2022.
articles.title: Russia will succeed in Ukraine unless US support continues: Pentagon chief

articles.description: Energy giants BP and Equinor have reported significant impairments on their US offshore wind power portfolios, highlighting the challenges facing the renewable energy industry. Danish company Orsted has also warned of impairments due to supply delays, high-interest rates, and a lack of tax credits. These setbacks raise questions about the future of offshore wind projects in the US, which President Joe Biden has championed as part of his climate change agenda. The industry has faced obstacles including inflation, financing costs, and insufficient subsidies, leading developers to renegotiate contracts or withdraw from projects.
articles.title: Explainer: Why US offshore wind industry is in doldrums

articles.description: A disturbing incident took place in New York, where a neighbor shot and killed a father and his stepson during an argument over noise. The incident was captured on video, showing the neighbor pacing angrily outside his neighbor's apartment before shooting the victims. The audio was not captured, so the exact conversation between the two is unclear. The neighbor calmly observed the scene before fleeing, but he has been identified by the police. The wife of the victim insists that her husband was not at fault and questions why the neighbor brought a gun to the argument.
articles.title: Man kills 2 over noise complaint in New York

articles.description: The Nordic governments, including Denmark, Sweden, Finland, Norway, and Iceland, have announced plans to strengthen their cooperation in returning immigrants without legal residence back to their countries of origin. Denmark's strict immigration policies have drawn criticism, but are now being viewed as a model by other Nordic countries. The governments have agreed to enhance cooperation between diplomatic personnel and arrange joint flights to return illegal residents.
articles.title: Nordic countries to cooperate more on returning migrants to countries of origin

articles.description: US secretary of state Antony Blinken accused Russian president Vladimir Putin of using the Israel-Hamas conflict to reduce Western support for Ukraine. Blinken stated that Putin hopes the Hamas attack on Israel will distract the US and result in a withdrawal of resources from Ukraine. Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin warned that without US support, Putin would be successful in seizing Ukrainian territory. The US is the largest donor of military aid to Ukraine.
articles.title: Putin seeking to 'take advantage' of Israel-Hamas war: Antony Blinken

articles.description: The U.S. Supreme Court is considering cases from California and Michigan to determine whether public officials can legally block critics on social media. Lower courts have reached different conclusions, highlighting the uncertainty around whether such actions are protected by the First Amendment. The justices are tasked with deciding whether the officials were acting in their personal capacity or engaged in "state action." Advocacy groups are urging the court to support the plaintiffs.
articles.title: US Supreme Court weighs if public officials can block critics on social media

articles.description: Former army general Chowdhury Hasan Suhrawardi has been arrested in Bangladesh for allegedly orchestrating a media appearance by a Bangladeshi-American who claimed to be a close advisor to US President Joe Biden. The American, Mian Zahidul Islam Arefy, has been charged with fraudulence and instigating anarchy, and Suhrawardi is accused of being the mastermind behind the scheme. The US embassy in Dhaka has stated that Arefy does not speak for the US government and is a private individual.
articles.title: Bangladesh: Retired army general arrested over fake 'Biden's adviser' connection

articles.description: During his fraud trial, FTX founder Sam Bankman-Fried was questioned about his relationship with Bahamian officials. The prosecutor sought to link favors done for the officials with Bankman-Fried's decision to allow FTX customers in the Bahamas to withdraw funds after withdrawals for others had been halted. Bankman-Fried, who is facing charges of fraud and conspiracy, denied offering to pay off the Bahamas' national debt but admitted to offering a job to the son of the Bahamian prime minister. He also stated that he could not recall whether he gave the prime minister and his wife seats at a Miami Heat game.
articles.title: Sam Bankman-Fried grilled on 'cozy' relationship with Bahamas officials

articles.description: A new poll shows that President Joe Biden's support among Arab Americans has dropped significantly, from 59% in 2020 to just 17% now. This decline in support is attributed to growing anger over Biden's support for Israel's attacks on Gaza. The poll also reveals that a majority of Arab Americans no longer identify as Democrats, with 32% identifying as Republicans and 31% as independents. The poll highlights the challenge Biden may face in winning over key Arab American voters.
articles.title: Biden's Arab American support drops amid Gaza conflict

articles.description: UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak is hosting a summit on AI safety, aiming to assert Britain's influence and gain an advantage in the technology. While state leaders have been hesitant to attend due to other global conflicts, Elon Musk will bring star power to the event with a live-streamed conversation on his social media platform, X. Sunak hopes to shape a global approach to AI regulation, with the summit serving as a test case for Britain's ability to set its own rules after Brexit.
articles.title: Rishi Sunak embraces Elon Musk to boost AI summit

articles.description:
Buildings destroyed after the earthquake on February 13, 2023, in Hatay, Turkey. | Murat Saka/dia images via Getty Images
    

  
Turkey is investigating and has arrested some contractors, but the entire political and economic system is implicated.
 Turkey is still in the middle of an emergency, reeling from the earthquake that killed at least 35,000 people last week. But the finger-pointing has already begun. 
The rush to punishment comes amid the grief, but also the mounting fury and frustration over the Turkish government’s earthquake response. Much of that is focused on the emergency response — waiting for aid and rescue teams — but it is also extending to anger about policies before the earthquake, about how shoddy building construction may have exacerbated the devastation of the dis…
articles.title: Who is responsible for Turkey’s bad buildings?

articles.description:
Getty Images
    

  
How we turned 20,000 Soviet nukes into zero-carbon energy — and how we can do the same with some of our own.
 Just a decade ago, one in 10 American lightbulbs was powered by dismantled Russian nuclear weapons.
That was made possible by the Megatons to Megawatts program, an agreement negotiated after the collapse of the Soviet Union to convert uranium from Russia’s nuclear weapons stockpile into fuel for US nuclear power plants. The unconventional policy was first proposed by MIT physicist Thomas Neff in a 1991 New York Times op-ed. By the time Megatons to Megawatts ran its full course from 1993 to 2013, it had eliminated about 20,000 nuclear warheads and stood out as a point of shared pride in the often jaded arms control and disarmament field. “Nearly every commercia…
articles.title: 10 years ago, we were turning nuclear bombs into nuclear energy. We can do it again.

articles.description:
Volunteers stand on rubble of a destroyed building in Kahramanmaras, Turkey, on February 7, 2023. | Adem Altan/AFP via Getty Images
    

  
What Turkey and Syria’s deadly earthquakes reveal about wealth.
 In the early hours of Monday, February 6, residents living in southern Turkey and northern Syria were woken by violent shaking, collapsing buildings, and sweeping blackouts. The earthquake buried residents in rubble and was followed by powerful aftershocks. By the following Monday, the death toll had passed 36,000 people. “It was like the apocalypse,” Abdul Salam al-Mahmoud, a resident of Atareb, Syria, told Reuters.  
The country is no stranger to quakes, having lost 17,000 people to a 7.4-magnitude tremor in 1999. But while last week’s earthquake was a 7.8-magnitude quake, and had an u…
articles.title: Why earthquakes are deadlier depending on where you live

articles.description:
A suspected Chinese spy balloon flies above Charlotte, North Carolina, on February 4, 2023.  | Peter Zay/Anadolu Agency via Getty Images
    

  
As all these objects fall, a new space race is rising.
 Now that the US military has shot down a suspected spy balloon from China and three other unidentified flying objects, there will be debates about the UFOs’ meaning, their capabilities, and why they were all up there in the first place. 
Though former CIA Director Michael Hayden said the initial balloon’s threat to the welfare of Americans was vastly inflated, others described the incident as a wake-up call. Former Trump national security adviser H.R. McMaster hopes it will lead to a “Sputnik moment,” harkening back to the US space race with the Soviet Union. The Wall Street Journal even war…
articles.title: Why the balloon and UFO affairs are a Sputnik moment

articles.description: A mob in a small town in Senegal dug up the body of a man suspected of being gay, dragged his body through the streets and then burned it during the night of October 28, 2023. While there have been other instances of exhumations of people suspected of being gay, the incident that took place in Kaolack, a town 200 kilometres southeast of Dakar, is different because it was filmed and posted online, says our Observer, a member of a group dedicated to upholding the human rights of LGBT Africans.

articles.description: Ten years ago, French radio journalists Ghislaine Dupont and Claude Verlon were murdered by a commando from al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb in the north-eastern Malian town of Kidal. Today, the vast area stretching from Mauritania to Sudan has become a no man's land for journalists, a black hole for news.

articles.description: After more than 600 days since the Russian invasion, psychics and fortune tellers offering predictions on when the war will end are becoming increasingly popular in Ukraine with some soothsayers’ military forecasts racking up hundreds of thousands of views on social media. articles.description: Some pro-Israeli social media users are claiming that Palestinians are posting videos pretending to be injured by the bombing campaign carried out by Israel since October 7. On October 26, for example, pro-Israeli accounts started sharing claims that a Palestinian video maker had pretended to be injured. Their so-called proof was two videos – one said to show the man in a hospital bed and the next one, apparently filmed the next day, showing him in perfect health. It turns out, however, that the video of the injured man is from August 2023, months before the war broke out. Moreover, it shows another man – and a real victim of the ongoing conflict.

articles.author: M.L. Nestel
articles.description:
She tried to censure and it came up short. 
Now she's shaming the names who didn't vote in favor. 
Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene (R-GA) had willed a resolution to censure Rep. Rashida Tlaib (D-MI) for her attendance of a protest opposing the war in Gaza. 
POLL: Should Trump be allowed to run for office?
"List of feckless Republicans that voted WITH Democrats to table my censure resolution against Rashida Tlaib," Greene said on Wednesday. "This is why Republicans NEVER do anything to stop the communists Democrats or ever hold anyone accountable!! PATHETIC."

She created a social media thread naming some of her friends in the House who didn't have what it took to vote with her. 
They include current House Speaker Mike Johnson, Rep. Chip Roy (R-TX), and Rep. Ken Buck (R-CO) who announced he wasn't running for reelection. 

	Earlier in the week, Greene preemptively lashed out after learning that her effort wasn't gaining a coalition in Congress.
"I want to remind you, this happened on the same day Hezbollah declared a day of immense anger," she said. "And Rashida Tlaib organized with that group. And they did. They did protest, and they did an insurrection into our Capitol complex, stopping Congress and stopping the Senate."
The media was quick to take notice of the lawmaker's swing and miss Wednesday.
"Colleague Kelly Phares rpts 23 GOPers join Dems to table or kill effort to censure Dem MI Rep Tlaib," tweeted Chat Pergram.
Melanie Zanona also tweeted: "motion to table — aka kill — MTG’s resolution to censure Rep. Rashida Tlaib just passed the House, with help of 23 Republicans."

And CNN's Manu Raju added that the effort to take on Tlaib quickly died tweeting: "House kills resolution to censure Rashida Tlaib. 23 Republicans voted with Dems. MTG offered the resolution."
articles.title: 'Pathetic': Marjorie Taylor Greene attacks 'feckless Republicans' who voted against her

articles.author: Sarah K. Burris
articles.description:
Sen. Tommy Tuberville's (R-AL) blockade appears to be coming to an end, according to an MSNBC report. 
Capitol reporter Ali Vitali said that a group of Republicans were going to take to the Senate floor and force a vote with Democrats to marginalize Tuberville's protest against military promotions that has led to a reduced military readiness for the United States, according to reports.
After a discussion about the absurdity of the protest, host Nicolle Wallace said that she recalled the era when Republicans had to be supportive of the military or they'd be shamed by leaders like Sen. Mitch McConnell (R-KY) and the GOP speaker. 
POLL: Should Trump be allowed to run for office?
Taking to social media, reporter Andrew Desiderio confirmed the reporting, saying that the floor actions will take place tonight, where they will ask for unanimous consent on ending the Tuberville blockade. He said that he was told it would be led by Sen. Dan Sullivan (R-AK). 
The news comes after reports that McConnell threatened Sen. Josh Hawley (R-MO) over his bill to stop corporations from being able to give money to campaigns. McConnell reportedly pointed to Hawley in the caucus lunch and said he wouldn't be there if it wasn't for the money from his Senate Leadership PAC. He went on to threaten any member who supported the bill with a primary. 
It's the first such action heard about from McConnell since he suffered serious injuries from a series of falls and then appeared to freeze at various public press availabilities.
articles.title: Republicans to join Dems in breaking Tuberville's blockade on military promotions: report

articles.author: M.L. Nestel
articles.description:
He drew a hard line in the sand, stalling hundreds of promotions of military brass. 
That line is budging. 
Officials are fuming at  Sen. Tommy Tuberville (R-AL) after it was discovered over the weekend that Marine Corps Commandant Gen. Eric Smith, who had been doubling as both the top No. 1 and No. 2 Marine Corps leader since July, suffered an apparent heart attack and was hospitalized on Sunday — leaving a three-star general to hold the prestigious post, according to a report published by Politico.
POLL: Should Trump be allowed to run for office?
The potential overextension of Smith and the stalling of more than 300 critical leadership roles was iced out by Tuberville's blockade installed as a protest against the Pentagon's policy to permit time off and reimbursement for abortions.  
Now…
articles.title: Tuberville's military blockade has 'added danger' after top Marine's heart attack: report

House Republicans, lead by newly minted Speaker Mike Johnson (R-LA), are demanding that the cost of the aid package to Israel be "offset" by $14 billion in cuts to IRS enforcement funding guaranteed in President Joe Biden's Inflation Reduction Act — which is not only unrelated to the issue at hand, but experts say it would actually increase the deficit.
The fact that Republicans are demanding an increase in tax evasion as their condition of supporting a key U.S. ally's military is not an accident, argued Talking Points Memo's Josh Marshall on MSNBC Tuesday, but a sign of how low the GOP has sunk.
"I have to say, Josh, like, Mike Johnson rolling out, going after the IRS on a must-pass is past even a caricature, I can imagine, of a priority from the Republican House speaker," said anchor Chr…

articles.author: Maya Boddie,  Alternet
articles.description:
After Marine Corps Gen. Eric Smith suffered landed in the hospital Sunday following "an apparent heart attack," Senate Armed Services Chair Jack Reed (D-Rhode Island) alleged U.S. Senator Tommy Tuberville's (R-Alabama) military promotions hold may have contributed, Politico reports.
Politico notes the Alabama senator "has maintained the blockade over the Pentagon's abortion travel policy, ensnaring more than 300 generals and admirals at the upper rungs of the armed forces."
Reed told the news outlet, "One of the reasons, I think contributed to his condition was he was doing two jobs at once. I've read where he was working from 5 a.m. to 11 p.m. As a result, if he had, as is normal, an assistant, he could switch off."
POLL: Should Trump be allowed to hold office again?
Per the report, he ad…

Newly appointed House Speaker Mike Johnson (R-LA) has a record of opposing military assistance to Ukraine. Since taking charge of the House, he has not outright said he will block Ukraine aid — but he has made clear it will not be coupled to his planned aid package to Israel, claiming the latter is more urgent of a need.
But if Johnson continues to obstruct Ukraine aid, he is headed for a "collision course" with his counterpart in Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-KY), who is committed to continuing to defend Eastern Europe against Russian aggression, reported Politico on Monday.
According to Burgess Everett, McConnell's outspoken lobbying efforts to sway Republican senators to passing Ukraine relief "is a sharp deviation from his usual more reserved, consensus-building approach" a…

articles.description:
British-Iranian actress Nazanin Boniadi has taken aim at the United Nations for enabling the Islamic Republic of Iran to use the organisation to “legitimise itself”.  

Ms Boniadi sat down with Sky News Australia host Laura Jayes to discuss the dangerous regime of the Islamic Republic of Iran.

Ms Boniadi urged the West to enforce sanctions on Iranian officials amid the rampant human rights abuses in the country.  

She said the Islamic Republic is using the United Nations to “normalise” itself to the global public. 

“The problem with the UN is … when UN member states and their representatives don’t stand for democracy, and they play into the Islamic Republic’s propaganda and side with them, then we’re never going to see change,” she told Sky News Australia.
articles.title: Nazanin Boniadi takes aim at UN for letting Iran ‘legitimise itself’

articles.description:
Social media users have reacted online after pro-Palestinian activists took over London's Liverpool Street Station to stage a sit-in protest, calling for an end to Israel's attacks on Gaza.
 
Over 500 pro-Palestinian activists organised a sit-in protest, denouncing the Israel-Hamas conflict.
 
The sit-in, orchestrated by the direct action group Sisters Uncut, featured Palestinian music and chants like "ceasefire now".
 
Various activist groups, including the Palestinian Youth Movement and International Jewish Anti-Zionist Network, joined the demonstration.
 
The protest concluded around 7 p.m. and the station continued its operations, a Network Rail spokeswoman confirmed.
 
British Transport Police responded to reports of the protest and reportedly ensured a safe dispersal of the crowd, allowing passengers access to the station.
 
A similar sit-in involving more than 200 people occurred at London Waterloo station on the preceding Saturday.
articles.title: ‘God help if you’re Jewish’: Liverpool Street station overrun by pro-Palestine protest

In 2014, T.X. Hammes wrote “Israel and the Demise of ‘Mowing the Grass‘” for War on the Rocks, in which he wrote that Israel’s practice of “mowing the grass,” in which they routinely “conduct a major operation[s] to reduce Hamas’ capabilities” could cost Israel in terms of international support and its own military casualties. In light of the Hamas attack on Israel on Oct. 7, Israel’s subsequent air campaign and, now, the ground campaign in Gaza, we asked T.X. to look back on his article. Read more below. Image via Sgt. Shay Wagner, IDF Spokesperson’s Unit In 2014, you wrote an
The post Rewind and Reconnoiter: Israel and the Demise of “Mowing the Grass” with T.X. Hammes appeared first on War on the Rocks.

articles.author: Leo Blanken
articles.description:
The shock of Hamas’ Oct. 7 assault continues to reverberate around the world amidst fears it will be the catalyst for a wider regional war. Many observers are comparing it to the 1973 Yom Kippur war, arguing that Israel repeated many of the same mistakes in failing to anticipate the attack. But this was more than an intelligence failure. It was failure of imagination. Israel grew comfortable managing its relationship with Hamas in Gaza, keeping rocket attacks and suicide bombings to a relatively low level for almost a decade. Moreover, as we saw in a visit last month, Israel’s top
The post Al-Aqsa Storm Heralds the Rise of Non-state Special Operations appeared first on War on the Rocks.

The role of U.S. allies and partners lies at the center of the U.S. defense strategy, as their military cooperation provides the United States with an edge that near-peer competitors like China and Russia cannot match. Yet, despite years of efforts by senior Department of Defense officials to make the defense acquisition system more agile and flexible, the system retains a culture inherently resistant to foreign cooperation because it was built for a prior era of U.S. technological dominance.   We have both served or currently serve as executives for defense and aerospace firms with interests in this issue. Our
The post Getting Serious About Enhancing U.S. Defense Partnerships appeared first on War on the Rocks.
articles.title: Getting Serious About Enhancing U.S. Defense Partnerships

articles.description:
Hamas’ unexpected and gruesome attack on Oct. 7 and Israel’s disproportionate effort to remove the group from power in Gaza constitute a watershed moment. Both Israeli and Palestinian societies are caught by the trauma of their interconnected histories and the violence of war. The myth of an invincible Israeli military and intelligence is broken. U.S. government efforts to recalibrate the regional order by facilitating Arab-Israeli normalization are disrupted, if not totally off the table in the near term. Arab states are worried about widening regional conflict and increasing public rage against Israel’s policy toward the occupied territories. Many in the
The post Turkey’s Response to the War in Gaza appeared first on War on the Rocks.

Axios: Where U.S. troops are stationed in the Middle East 

With the Israel-Hamas war escalating, the United States risks becoming involved in a larger conflict that could entangle some of the more than 40,000 U.S. military personnel based across the region.

 
Why it matters: U.S. troops and military contractors in Iraq and Syria have been targeted in over a dozen attacks by Iranian-backed militia groups since Hamas' surprise attack against Israeli civilians and soldiers on Oct. 7. 
 * Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin has warned of the "prospect of a significant escalation of attacks on our troops and our people throughout the region." 
 * Between the lines: The attacks, as well as a wider war, could reverse efforts in recent years to reduce the U.S. presence in the Middle East as part of a strategic pivot to toward the Pacific.

 
Read more ....

 
WNU Editor: More U.S. troops are being deployed .... US Sends 300 More Troops To Middle East (Zero Hedge/Epoch Times).
articles.title: There Are Currently 40,000 U.S. Ground Troops In The Middle East

articles.description:
Saudi Arabia Eurofighter Typhoon – Wikipedia

 

EruAsian Times: French Rafales ‘Trounce’ Eurofighters As Germany Blocks Sale Of Typhoon Jets To Saudi Arabia – Reports

 
Germany loosened export restrictions against Saudi Arabia earlier this year. Still, it refused to allow the sale of the 4.5th generation Eurofighter Typhoon fighter jet to the kingdom, despite the UK government’s intense lobbying. Berlin’s refusal, unfortunately, poses a significant challenge to Britain’s production lines. 
The United Kingdom is likely to see a loss of 6,000 jobs in the defense sector and no manufacturing of fighter jets for a decade in the face of Germany’s unwillingness to green-light the sale of Eurofighter Typhoon jets to the Royal Saudi Air Force, British newspaper The Sun reported.
Berlin is blocking a multibillion-dollar agreement to sell 48 Typhoons to Saudi Arabia, and ministers have threatened to “close” BAE production lines if the contract is refused. German Chancellor Olaf Scholz clarified in July this year that Germany will not deliver Eurofighter combat aircraft to Saudi Arabia soon.

 
Read more ....

 
WNU Editor: The impact on the UK for losing this sale is going to be huge .... More than 6,000 UK jobs are put at risk as Germany controversially BLOCKS a deal to sell British-made Typhoon fighter jets to Saudi Arabia (Daily Mail).
articles.title: Germany Blocks Sale Of Typhoon Jets To Saudi Arabia

articles.description:
Reuters: North Korea closes multiple embassies around the world

 
North Korea is poised to close as many as a dozen embassies including in Spain, Hong Kong, and multiple countries in Africa, according to media reports and analysts, in a move that could see nearly 25 percent of Pyongyang's missions close worldwide. 
North Korea's recent closing of its diplomatic missions was a sign that the reclusive country is struggling to make money overseas because of international sanctions, South Korea's unification ministry said on Tuesday. 
On Monday, North Korean state media outlet KCNA said the country's ambassadors paid "farewell" visits to Angolan and Ugandan leaders last week, and local media in both African countries reported the shutdown of the North's embassies there. 

 
Read more ....

 
WNU Editor: Running an embassy or any other diplomatic office is not cheap. And with the West enforcing sanctions, it makes no economic sense to have one in a place like Angola or Uganda. 
 North Korea Closes A Dozen Embassies Around The World
North Korea shuts down multiple embassies, South Korea speculates financial issues are the reason -- FOX News
 
North Korea closes several overseas embassies amid sanctions woes -- UPI
 
Why North Korea is shutting over dozen embassies across world -- The Independent
articles.title: North Korea Closes A Dozen Embassies Around The World

articles.description:
Al-Monitor: West Bank death toll exceeds 120 as US warns Israel over settler violence 
Over 120 Palestinians in the West Bank have been killed amid raids by the Israeli army and settler attacks since Oct. 7. 
As Israel expands its ground incursion in the Gaza Strip, violence in the West Bank is also escalating, with at least 115 Palestinians killed and more than 2,000 injured since the Israel-Hamas war started on Oct. 7, according to the United Nations. 
Clashes between Palestinians in the West Bank and the Israel Defense Forces as well as attacks by Jewish settlers are common, but both have intensified in recent weeks. 
The IDF has been conducting an increasing number of raids in the West Bank since the Oct. 7 Hamas attack on southern Israel killed 1,400 Israelis, mostly civilians. Since then, more than 8,500 Palestinians have been killed in the subsequent Israeli bombardment of the Gaza Strip. 
Read more .... 
Violence Is Surging In The West Bank

 
Palestinian death toll from Israeli gunfire in West Bank rises to 124 since Oct. 7 -- Anadolu Agency
 
Dozens arrested, killed in West Bank and Gaza in Israeli raids overnight -- Al Jazeera 
'Israeli army' claims to have arrested 740 Hamas members in West Bank since Oct. 7 -- Roya News
 
1,680 arrested in West Bank since October 7 -- Jordan News
articles.title: Violence Is Surging In The West Bank

articles.description:
The Long War Journal: Houthis launch third strike against Israel, threaten more attacks 
The Israel Defense Forces intercepted a missile and two drones over the Red Sea that were fired by Ansar Allah, the Iran-backed group in Yemen more commonly known as the Houthis, earlier today. The attack marked the third by the Houthis that has targeted Israel, and the terror group has threatened more as Israel pushes its ground offensive into Gaza. 
The missiles and two drones were launched from the “Red Sea area” and shot down “outside the territory of the State of Israel,” the IDF said, according to The Times of Israel. The Houthi missile was shot down with the Arrow air defense system, while Israel Air Force fighters downed the two Houthi drones.
Read more .... 
Yemen's Houthis Have Officially Waded Into The Israel-Hamas War

Israel rushes missile boats to Red Sea after Yemen’s Houthis declare war -- The Telegraph 
Israel Missile Ships Deployed to Red Sea Amid Yemen Threat -- Newsweek 
Israel beefs up defenses around Eilat following Houthi attacks -- Times of Israel
articles.title: Yemen's Houthis Have Officially Waded Into The Israel-Hamas War

Top Biden administration officials warned senators on Tuesday that if they approve aid to Israel but cut out funding for Ukraine, Vladimir Putin will win. 
Secretary of State Antony Blinken and Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin argued against decoupling President Joe Biden’s $106 billion supplemental request for Israel, Ukraine and the Pacific while testifying before the Senate Appropriations Committee. 
The pair warned Russia would prevail without continued U.S. assistance and would have implications outside of Europe.

FOX News: Pakistan set to deport over 1.4 million undocumented Afghan nationals; UN seeks relief on deadline

 
Pakistan’s government announced a major crackdown earlier this month 
Pakistan's government plans to deport over 1.4 million Afghan nationals after November 1, and the United Nations is calling for the country to hold off to avoid human rights violations. 
The Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights (OHCHR) said in a press release that it is "extremely alarmed" by Pakistan’s deportation announcement, as there are currently over two million undocumented Afghans living in the country. 
Of the two million, more than 600,000 are immigrants who left Afghanistan after the Taliban reclaimed power in August 2021.

 
Read more ....

articles.description:
CNBC: Biden will meet with China’s Xi Jinping next month, White House says 
* President Joe Biden will meet with Chinese President Xi Jinping next month. 
 * The meeting will take place on the sidelines of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation, or APEC, summit in San Francisco. 
WASHINGTON — President Joe Biden will meet with Chinese President Xi Jinping next month, the White House announced on Tuesday. 
The leaders of the world’s two largest economies are expected to meet on the sidelines of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation, or APEC, summit in San Francisco. 
“Intense competition means intense diplomacy,” White House press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre said at a press briefing. “Our policy and how we move forward with China has not changed.” 
Jean-Pierre declined to provide details about Biden’s agenda other than he is expected to have “a tough conversation” with Xi.

 
Read more ....

CNN: ‘Children were carrying other injured children’: Witness describes aftermath of Israeli strike on Gaza refugee camp  
Jerusalem CNN — An Israeli strike targeting a Hamas commander in the densely populated Jabalya refugee camp in northern Gaza has left catastrophic damage and killed a large number of people, according to eyewitnesses and medics in the enclave.
“I was waiting in line to buy bread when suddenly and without any prior warning seven to eight missiles fell,” an eyewitness, Mohammad Ibrahim, told CNN. 
“There were seven to eight huge holes in the ground, full of killed people, body parts all over the place,” he said. “It felt like the end of the world.”

WNU Editor: Dropping a bomb to kill one Hamas commander even though it would mean hundreds of civilians killed and wounded. Hamas's massacre of Israeli citizens on October 7 has now resulted in a conflict where the rules of war no longer apply.

Iran today boasted its powerful proxies 'won't stay silent' and hinted the fighting between Israel and Hamas could engulf the Middle East after the Tehran-backed Huthi rebels fired drones into the Jewish state from Yemen. 
The Huthis, who seized Yemen's capital Sanaa in 2014 and control large swathes of the country, said they fired a series of drones towards the Red Sea city of Eilat this morning in retaliation to Israel's war against Hamas. 
'These drones belong to the state of Yemen. We are fighting with words and drones,' Abdelaziz bin Habtour, prime minister of the Huthi government, said.

articles.description:
🚨What every American should know about Biden's $105B aid package- 
It leverages the attacks against Israel to send BILLONS more to Ukraine, slows down Israel from getting the help they need in their time of war, does nothing to actually secure our borders, & is DOA in the House. pic.twitter.com/Ytf3V4mhMS
— Dr. Roger Marshall (@RogerMarshallMD) October 28, 2023
  
Zero Hedge: Bills On Israel, Ukraine 'Dead On Arrival' In Both House And Senate As Shutdown, Funding Battles Gear Up 
As the nation celebrates Halloween, the House and Senate are engaged in some spooky late-stage Republic chaos over aid to Israel and Ukraine amid a backdrop of yet another government shutdown looming in two weeks. 
* The government will run out of money (again) in roughly two weeks, requiring Congress to act (again). 
* According to Democrats and GOP Neocons such as Mitch McConnell and Lindsey Graham, America needs to send billions of taxpayer funds to both Israel and Ukraine, and won't consider any legislation that doesn't combine the two. 
* House Republicans under newly minted Speaker Mike Johnson (R-LA), as well as a group of Senate Republicans, want Israel aid separated from Ukraine aid, while the Biden White House wants to jam a $105 billion foreign aid package ($14B to Israel, $60B to Ukraine) through Congress. 
* The House's plan (if they can even pass it) to separate Israel aid from Ukraine aid is DOA in the Senate, while both the Senate's combined package and the Biden admin's package is DOA in the House.

 
Read more ....

 
WNU Editor: I am confident that both the House and Senate will come to an agreement on this aid. But it is going to take time.
articles.title: Are The U.S. Administration's Bills On Israel, Ukraine Aid 'Dead On Arrival' In Both House And Senate?

articles.description:
The Hill: Blinken, Austin testify on $100B national security funding request 
Secretary of State Antony Blinken and Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin are slated to testify Tuesday morning in a hearing before the Senate Appropriations Committee, regarding the Biden administration’s more than $100 billion emergency aid request for conflicts in Israel and Ukraine. 
The majority of Democrats and many Republican senators support tying aid for the two countries together. 
But, the aid request faces much deeper problems in the Republican-led House, where new Speaker Mike Johnson has proposed cutting out the Ukraine aid and focusing on Israel alone. He’s also proposed cutting money for the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) to pay for it, as The Associated Press reported. 
 Read more ....

 
WNU Editor: There were a number of protests during the hearing (see video below).
articles.title: Secretaries Blinken & Austin Testify On $100B National Security Funding Request For Israel And Ukraine

U.S. Marine Gen. Eric M. Smith, the Assistant Commandant of the Marine Corps, speaks to Marines from Marine Corps Recruiting Station Montgomery and Weapons Company, 3rd Battalion 23rd Marines at Maxwell Air Force Base in Montgomery, Alabama, Feb. 10, 2023. U.S. Marine Corps Photo

 

DNYUZ/New York Times: Top Marine General Hospitalized After Apparently Having Heart Attack 
Gen. Eric M. Smith, the Marine Corps’s commandant and top officer, was hospitalized on Sunday evening after an unspecified medical emergency, the service said on Monday. 
The Marines announced General Smith’s hospitalization in an email to reporters but provided no further details about his condition. One current and one former defense official familiar with his condition said he apparently had a heart attack while jogging.

 
Read more ....

 
WNU Editor: A three-star is now in charge .... Top Marine general hospitalized, leaving 3-star in charge (Marine Times). More here .... With Gen. Smith hospitalized, a 3-star is in command of Marine Corps (Breaking Defense). 
Gen. Eric M. Smith, The Marine Corps’s Commandant And Top Officer,  Hospitalized After Apparently Having Heart Attack

 
UPDATED: Marine Commandant Gen. Eric Smith Hospitalized After Heart Attack -- USNI News

articles.description:
‼️ Record High Displacement in #DRCongo
 More people than ever before, nearly 7 million, are internally displaced. Amid growing displacement and increased violence, humanitarian needs are soaring.
 More in our latest press release 👇https://t.co/oF7KmqrkaN pic.twitter.com/eN3UZk8PJJ
— IOM - UN Migration 🇺🇳 (@UNmigration) October 30, 2023
  
France 24: A record 6.9 million people are internally displaced in DR Congo, says UN 
Escalating violence has pushed the number of people internally displaced within the Democratic Republic of Congo to a record 6.9 million, the United Nations said Monday. 
The conflict between M23 rebels and militias loyal to the DRC's government has intensified in the eastern province of North Kivu since early October, particularly north of the provincial capital Goma. 
The UN's International Organization for Migration said many people who have fled their homes but stayed within the DRC's borders desperately needed help to meet their basic needs.

 
Read more ....

 
Update: UN says record 6.9 million people internally displaced in the DR Congo (Africa News)

 
WNU Editor: Quoting The UN's International Organization for Migration (IOM) ....  "With ongoing conflict and escalating violence, the DRC is facing one of the largest internal displacement and humanitarian crises in the world."
articles.title: UN Says A Record 6.9 Million People Are Internally Displaced In DR Congo
